_header: For when the roof of thine hous lieth upon thy nose
Title(s): ‘Al thys werldly blisse to the ne is worith a pese’
Subjects: sermons, verse in; transitoriness, of world
_description: ‘Al thys werldly blisse to the ne is worith a pese’ — a proverbial couplet in a sermon by Brinton

CULIi38.Transcription:
For whan þe rofe of þyn hous lithe on þi neseAlle
                    þe worldis blisse ys nouth worthe a pese
CULIi38.Editions:
Owst,  Gerald Robert. 
             Literature and Pulpit in Medieval England.
         Cambridge: UP, 1933: 43.
Stemmler,  Theo. 
             “More English Texts from MS. Cambridge University Library
                Ii.III.8.” 
             Anglia
         93 (1975): 1-16: 16.

BLHar3760.Transcription:
For whan þe roof of þyn hous lith vpon þy neseal
                    þys werdly blisse to þe ne is worith a pese
BLHar3760.Note: Written as Prose. Shortened version on f. 244v.
